SPEECH.SPEAKER: MULVIHILL

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 44 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania. As this area is on the Register of the National Estate it is therefore of national concern and your petitioners humbly call upon the Senate to conduct a Senate Inquiry into South West Tasmania. A Federal Inquiry has been recommended by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate funds or allow funds to be raised for development of roads or dams in the South West of Tasmania but rather to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights in Sri Lanka
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

When Imperial Britain left the shores of Ceylon, she introduced the Soulbury constitution in 1948 which handed over parliamentary power almost exclusively to the majority Sinhalese community. The Sinhalese leadership interpreted and implemented its political power by such acts as:
1. Disenfranchising nearly one million Tamils in 1948.
2. Declaring Sinhalese as the ONLY official language of the country in 1956. Thus disadvantaging the Tamil speaking population in employment, education and administrative matters.
3. Demanding Tamil children be educated in Sinhalese for employment in government sector.

4. Government sponsored colonisation of traditional Tamil districts, with the eventual objective of depriving Tamil representation of those areas in the legislative assembly. This has happened in areas where colonisation has taken place in the Eastern Province.

5. Discrimination against the development of Tamil areas by channelling the foreign assistance schemes almost entirely to develop Sinhalese districts. A study of the developmental projects utilising Australian aid would be revealing.

6. A more important aspect of such discriminatory policies was the well planned and government encouraged attempts at the physical elimination of the Tamil people by acts of terrorism, plunder, rape and murder at regular intervals. Communal riots occurred in 1956; 1958; 1961; 1966; 1972; 1977; 1981.

During May and June 1981 the government security forces unleashed violence in the Tamil district of Jaffna, killing innocent people, set ablaze shops, homes and public library with historic Tamil documents, Tamil bookshops, newspaper offices and printery, presumably in an attempt to destroy Tamil identity and culture.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:

Urge the Federal Government of Australia to raise the problem of human rights of the Tamils of Sri Lanka as a matter for consideration at the forthcoming conference of the Commonwealth Heads of Government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: GOVERNMENT CLOTHING FACTORY AND ORDNANCE FACTORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, contingent on the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations reporting to the Senate that it is unable to inquire expeditiously into the matter referred to it by the Senate on 26 August 1981 relating to the Government Clothing Factory at Coburg and the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent me moving the following motion:
That:

(1) the resolution of the Senate of 26 August 1981 referring to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations the Government's decision to sell the Government Clothing Factory at Coburg and the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo be rescinded;
(2) a select committee be established on the future of the Government Clothing Factory at Coburg and the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo;
(3) the select committee report to the Senate by the first sitting day in November 1981 on the future of the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo; and
(4) the composition and powers of the select committee be contained in a subsequent resolution.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the fact that it was revealed recently that the figure of $12m quoted by the Government spokesman in respect of the cost of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting does not include a number of items which should have been included, such as the total cost of the Queen's visit and the cost of transport between Melbourne and Canberra-two items which were specifically cited. Is the Minister able to provide the Senate, if not today, shortly, with an itemised and complete account of how much the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting will cost the Australian Government?

—I will refer Senator Button's question to the relevant Minister. The costs must be viewed against the background that CHOGM will bring together in Australia some 41 or 42 heads of government in the world who represent something like one quarter or more of the nations of the world. I think it is a great tribute to Australia that the function should be held here. It is a very important function and will obviously be costly. The Australian community will, I think, be willing to accept that, for something which affects the well-being and the economic and political stability of peoples of one quarter of the world, the cost is well merited. It is our contribution towards international understanding and the improvement and the well-being of nations, particularly developing nations. Against that background I will endeavour to obtain further figures and inform Senator Button.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and relates to the current strike by Overseas Telecommunications Commission employees. The strike has had a major impact on Australian importers and exporters, preventing them from sending messages overseas and severely restricting incoming messages. Firstly, has this industrial action restricted media services from overseas or have the bans been selective? Secondly, is there a conspiracy of silence concerning this strike which seems not to be reported in any of today's newspapers? Thirdly, is the Government aware of this industrial action and the impact it is having on Australian businesses involved overseas? Finally, what is the Government doing to relieve this burden on these industries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware of the industrial dispute within the OTC caused by bans which have been imposed by the Professional Radio and Electronics Institute of Australasia. We are also aware that the bans are now having operational effects on the services of the OTC. We are concerned. A conference, chaired by Public Service Arbitrator Watson, was held on 14 September, at which the OTC outlined details of the work bans and sought an order directing the PREI and its members to lift the bans and prohibiting them from applying the bans. I am sorry to have to report that the PREI representative indicated that his members would not comply with such an order if it were issued.

ANSWER.PARA: The Public Service Board has indicated that it is undertaking a pay survey in respect of the physical grades of technical staff and that a common date of effect for any increases would be offered as a result of the survey. This is in answer to the last part of the honourable senator's question about what is being done. The Public Service Arbitrator has called for a further conference on Thursday or Friday of this week, today or tomorrow. There is no prospect of settlement of the dispute while the bans remain in force, and the implications of the bans are under urgent and critical examination. The honourable senator asks specifically about whether the bans are selective and whether the Australian Press is applying some conspiracy of silence-I think those were the honourable senator's words-in relation to the dispute. I will have to refer those matters to my colleague and obtain information for the honourable senator. I would sincerely hope that the reporting of this dispute would be the normal reporting and that there would be no attempt to hide its effects from the Australian public.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Acting Minister for Health. I refer to his statement made last night relating to the Government's mistake over the health insurance arrangements involving its agreement with the States and claims for pharmaceuticals in hospitals under sections 99 and 94 of the National Health Act. Was that statement a result of an actual attempt by a State or States to claim under both sections? If so, which State or States? What are the details of the claim or claims?

—There was no mistake involved. I just remind the Senate of the situation: Before the hospital cost sharing agreements came into force in 1975, there was a mechanism which provided for this reimbursement. Between 1975 and 1 September this year there was a different agreement. Now that that agreement is no longer in place, it is necessary to revoke those former approvals. There has been no mistake. This is appropriate action being taken to protect against the possibility of double payment. The honourable senator asks me specifically whether any State has actually made a such claim and whether our action is a response to such a claim. I think that states the question correctly. To the best of my knowledge there has been no such claim by any State and the action that is being proposed is action to prevent any such claim being made.

—I ask the Acting Minister for Health: Is it a fact that over recent years we have spent a greatly increased proportion of our national income on health care without any perceptible improvement in the health of our community? Are doctors' fees for services a significant part of this health care cost explosion? Has the Minister seen reports that the Australian Medical Association has claimed to Dr Isaac, who is conducting an inquiry into medical fees, that the overheads of a medical practice have risen in the last eight years from 44 per cent to no less than 56 per cent of the gross income of the practice? Has the Government any independent evidence to support this extraordinary claim, bearing in mind that the overhead level claimed is almost twice as high as that claimed in Canada? Will the Minister see whether the Government can provide the inquiry with some realistic figures on this key issue in medical costs? Might not the result be that the charge for services might fairly come down instead of go up, to the great benefit of the community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —While it is correct to say that health costs have increased over recent qears, it is not correct to say that there has been no discernible improvement in health outcomes. It might be fair to say that there has not been as much improvement in health outcomes as we might have hoped, but I refer the honourable senator, for example, to the dramatic downturn in the incidence and outcomes of ischaemic heart disease-coronary disease-which have improved markedly. It is noted that the AMA's first submission to the 1981 medical fees inquiry makes reference to the fact that at 30 September 1976 the medical fee index for general practitioners contained a cost component of about 45 per cent and an income component of about 55 per cent. According to the AMA's most recent survey, which covers the year ending 30 June 1980, these components were then about 56 per cent cost and 44 per cent income. I point out that in its submissions to the medical fees inquiries the Government has levelled some criticisms at the quality and representativeness of the AMA survey data. To that extent I can confirm the point the honourable senator makes.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not aware of similar studies conducted in Canada and I am unable therefore to comment on any comparison between Australian and Canadian experience. However, I point out that there could be some fallacy in using percentage figures because if, for example, Canadian doctors had double the gross income of Australian doctors they might well have higher practice costs but the percentages might be different. Nor am I able to comment on the proposition that, given that Canadian doctors have a lower practice cost to gross income ratio, they are in any way better business managers. I think that was implicit in the honourable senator's question. Similarly, I am not aware of the taxation provisions which apply federally and provincially in Canada. I am unable to comment on whether it is more or less difficult to obtain taxation advantages in Canada than in Australia. However, if the honourable senator requires more information or if more information is available, I will certainly undertake to make it available to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Is it a fact that about three weeks ago officials of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union notified the Department of Primary Industry of the possibility of contaminated meat either in or having passed through cold stores at Townsville, Port Hedland, Wyndham and Adelaide? If so, what action did the Department take on the report?
—I have no information on the matter raised by the honourable senator. I will seek a reply from the Minister for Primary Industry.

—I ask the Minister for National Development and Energy: What attitude does the Federal Government hold in regard to the Tasmanian Government's recent decision to conduct a referendum on the future of the Franklin hydro-electric power proposals? What contribution would the Commonwealth be called on to make and what input would the Commonwealth have as to the ultimate design or location if a dam were to be proceeded with?

—As I understand it, the Tasmanian Government has announced that it proposes to put to a referendum some questions as to alternatives for proceeding with electric power generation in Tasmania-specifically, hydro-electric power. Whilst the Commonwealth Government has a keen general interest in the whole matter-an interest to ensure that the State itself has adequate and continuing electric power and an interest in general conservation-the matter is and must remain a Tasmanian Government one. I do not want to comment further at this moment. I shall be interested to follow the progress of the referendum, including the questions to be asked. Tasmania vitally needs electric power. The Commonwealth Government, of course, set up the Zeidler Committee to inquire into the possibilities of an electric power grid involving the four States in south-eastern Australia. That concept would involve at some stage in the future a cable under Bass Strait. My instinct is that in the longer term Tasmania would benefit from such a connection. To that extent the Commonwealth has a very real interest. We have an interest because the resources development of Australia cannot be pursued and full employment guaranteed to people unless power generation is at the optimum level. I shall follow the developments with very keen interest.

—My question, which is directed to the Acting Minister for Health, refers to the drug depo-provera which has been recently rejected by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee as not being suitable for use as a contraceptive on the grounds that there are 'unresolved questions relating to its safety for this indication'. Is the Minister aware of allegations that a medical practitioner in the Australian Capital Territory recently revealed in an Australian Broadcasting Commission talk-back program that he administers depo-provera to women for use as a contraceptive and overcomes the illegality of this practice by describing a different purpose for the drug? Can the Minister say whether there is any truth in this allegation and, if there is, what action he proposes to take against the offending doctor? Further, if the Minister finds that there is substance to the allegations, will he take steps to find out how widespread this abuse is and indicate what steps will be taken by the Department of Health to end a practice which is clearly counter to the best interests and good health of the female patients of the doctors engaged in the deception? Finally, does the Minister not agree that the apparent complacency with which some male doctors perpetrate such drug abuse on their female patients, when they are far more cautious with what they prescribe for their own sex, is a sorry indictment of those members of the profession participating in the practice?

—I was impressed with the matters revealed by Senator Haines, with the exception of the last part of the question which I thought was unnecessary. I am not aware of the allegations. They have not been drawn to my attention. I regard them as significant allegations. I will undertake to find out what I can about them. I do not know of any medical practitioner in the Australian Capital Territory who has set out to circumvent regulations in the way the honourable senator has suggested. For that reason I cannot anwer all the other parts of the question. I indicate that the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee is held in high standing and that its recommendations and recommended indications for drug use are ones which most people in the medical profession would back and endorse.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINES AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDERS LEGAL SERVICE

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs aware that the Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders Legal Service is not permitted to do conveyancing on behalf of Aborigines and islanders in those purchases where the Aborigine or islander concerned qualifies for and is granted an Aboriginal Development Commission housing loan? Further, as all transactions are carried out between the purchaser and a nominated building society, can the Minister advise why the Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders Legal Service is not permitted to act in these instances?

—One of the first bushfires I was ask to attend to after I became Minister for Aboriginal Affairs was a problem involving the Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders Legal Service in Queensland. It was in some financial difficulties at that time. It became clear that the resources available required the Legal Service to set some priorities in terms of the classes of work which it undertook. Criminal work was clearly the most important and the Legal Service indicated that a priority list existed. The feeling has been that conveyancing work, while important to individual Aboriginals, is a lesser priority and that the Legal Service should direct the available funds to the very great need for representation in court for Aboriginals in Queensland. So it has been a matter of allocating resources and using the priority setting. I think it is for this reason that conveyancing work is not carried out by ATSILS.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: INCOME TAX AVOIDANCE: AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING COMMISSION PROGRAM

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Communications aware that a private investment consultant, Mr Bruce Bond, is a regular guest on the Australian Broadcasting Commission talk-back radio program Brian Minards Morning in Canberra? Is he also aware that on a recent occasion this consultant gave advice to callers on ways of avoiding tax on income from their investments? Does the Minister consider it appropriate for the ABC to provide opportunities for those in private business to advertise their services in this way? What action will he take to ensure that the ABC is not used as a vehicle for tax avoidance advice?

—I am aware of the public activities of Mr Bruce Bond. I remember listening to him many years ago at the Sydney Stock Exchange. That is where he used to work. I take it that he has now undertaken a different line of activity. I am not aware that this gentleman has been promoting or advocating tax avoidance on a program, as the honourable senator suggests. I will undertake to have the matter investigated and try to provide her with an answer to the consequential questions she asked.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to the Senate debate of 29 May 1981 on the proposed amendments to clauses then numbered 34 and 35 but now numbered 39 and 40 of the Freedom of Information Bill, when he refused to accept amendments adding a public interest test to exemptions in the Bill. I ask the Attorney-General whether, in debate on these amendments, he gave the following undertaking:

QUESTION.PARA: I recognise the great concern that a number of honourable senators have in relation to clauses 34 and 35. I will give the matter-and invite the Government to do the same-reconsideration before the Bill is dealt with in another place.

Will the Attorney-General confirm that there was and is dispute as to the terms of the arrangement between him and a number of Government senators relating to these amendments and to similar amendments to clauses now numbered 43 and 44? Since debate on the Bill has already commenced in the House of Representatives, I further ask the Attorney-General: Has the Government now reconsidered its attitude towards these four public interest amendments to the Bill? If so, will the Government honour the agreement made with Government senators and incorporate these public interest tests in the Bill?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall the debate in the Senate on the matter raised by Senator Missen. I do not know whether it was on 29 May. I accept the facts as he retailed them. It is true that I did give an undertaking, I think both inside and outside the Senate, that I would give further consideration to these amendments to incorporate a public interest test in certain exemptions in the Freedom of Information Bill. I have done that. I gave an undertaking that I would raise the matter with the Government and I have also done that. The debate on the Bill in the House of Representatives has been deferred pending the Government's consideration of the matters that I have raised. Admittedly the second reading debate has proceeded; but, as these would be matters for the Committee stage, I do not think there has been any breach of any undertaking by allowing the second reading debate to proceed. As I said, the Government has reconsidered the matter and has decided that it will continue to be opposed to amendments introducing a public interest test as included in the amendments before the Senate referred to by Senator Missen.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator asked me whether I would concede that there was a dispute with Government senators about discussions in relation to the Government's attitude to these amendments. I concede that there was a dispute between Senator Missen and me; but, as far as I am aware, he is the only senator who felt there was a misunderstanding.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not so.
—That is my understanding of the situation.

—Is the Acting Minister for Health aware of the conflicting remarks made by the Minister for Health and the Minister for Administrative Services regarding the future of the quarantine station at North Head in Sydney? Is he aware that the Minister for Administrative Services has on at least two occasions this year expressed hope that the Federal Government can relocate the quarantine station as quickly as possible to allow the New South Wales Government full use of the land again after having leased it to the Commonwealth in 1910? Is he also aware that the Minister for Health, on the other hand, has persistently refused to acknowledge the Department of Administrative Services negotiations with the New South Wales Government and has claimed that the New South Wales Government will have to provide an alternative quarantine facility costing $2m before the Commonwealth will agree to hand over the North Head station? Finally, is he aware that the New South Wales Government has already agreed to pay the Commonwealth $5m to relocate its rarely used quarantine facilities? When can the residents of Sydney expect North Head to be incorporated into the Sydney Harbour National Park?

—I am aware that there has been a very difficult and long history in trying to reach agreement between the New South Wales Government and the Commonwealth to get the harbour foreshores of Sydney returned to the people as they should be returned. I am also aware that the Minister for Health is the local member for the area in which the quarantine station is located. Mr MacKellar has a very keen interest in that part of Sydney which he represents so well. As to whether--
—Senator Sibraa is the local senator for the area.

—Many of us grew up in that area-not only Senator Sibraa. I also grew up in that area. I am not aware of any disagreement between the Ministers as Senator Sibraa suggests. It will obviously be necessary to seek from them details of what was said, information on whether there is any disagreement and the answers to the honourable senator's particular questions.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Transport to a report in the Courier-Mail of 16 September in which a tourist developer in the Whitsunday region claims that the curfew imposed on Brisbane Airport between 9 p.m. and midnight will seriously affect the Queensland tourist industry. This curfew is a deplorable state of affairs, but to my knowledge the only domestic regular passenger transport flights affected by the curfew are the last two evening flights into Brisbane. Will the Minister advise whether these are recognised as regular tourist flights and, if so, will the tourist traffic to the northern Queensland resorts be affected?

—I understand from the Minister that the honourable senator's understanding of this situation is correct and that in fact no major scheduled northbound passenger flights from Brisbane to the coastal tourist towns of Queensland are affected by the closure at 9 p.m. The two flights which have arrived nightly at Brisbane between 9 p.m. and 9.30 p.m., and which the airlines have rescheduled to arrive before 9 p.m. until the commencement of daylight saving in the southern States, are normal scheduled services. It seems, therefore, that there will in fact be no effect upon the tourist trade between Brisbane and the northern coastal towns of Queensland.

—I direct my question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. In November 1978 the United States Congress amended the Energy Conservation Program relating to consumer products and called for energy efficient standards for 13 categories of products. In view of the rising electricity costs, can the Minister inform the Senate whether any directives or incentives have been given to Australian manufacturers of white goods to improve the energy efficiency of household appliances and to conserve power and, of course, the cost?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My Department is keenly interested in the question of energy efficiency, and a number of research bodies, including advisory bodies, also are taking a keen interest. My Department will be seeking to give a lead for all Australians, whether in industry or in commerce, to conserve electricity, that is, to use less where they can. Clearly, in a domestic home one can become more energy efficient simply by not leaving on an extra light. I regard Senator Elstob's question as a significant one. It is indeed essential to obtain more efficient machines. To give the honourable senator some idea of what could be achieved, I point out that, if we could effect a saving of between 10 per cent and 20 per cent in the use of electric power in Australia, in every decade we would avoid the need to build two large power stations. We would save something in the order of $2 billion and therefore, because we would have more electric power available, we would be able to employ more people. The thrust of Senator Elstob's question-how to achieve more energy efficiency, whether in regard to the use of electricity or otherwise-is important.

ANSWER.PARA: We have an arrangement with the automotive industry whereby vehicles, which some three years ago consumed on average 11.2 litres for every 100 kilometres of travel, should have that consumption reduced to 9 litres for every 100 kilometres by 1983 and to 8 litres for every 100 kilometres by 1987. I am happy to say that, when we measured the situation at the end of the last year, the 11.2 litre average had been reduced to 9.9 litres. Therefore, we have two years in which to reduce the figure from 9.9 litres to 9 litres. I think that is possible. Reductions will become increasingly difficult to achieve. The answer to Senator Elstob's question is yes, there is pressure in Australia to achieve more energy efficiency; but, more importantly, we have a program called the National Industrial Energy Management Scheme or NIEMS, the aim of which is to achieve energy conservation and efficiency in industry. When required we provide experts to carry out energy audits of industry. That is proceeding now. Much more can be done and must be done in the kinds of areas that Senator Elstob has raised. Because it is a big subject and because I do not want to hold up Question Time, I will make further information available to the honourable senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs to a report in today's Australian which states that South Australia has asked the Federal Government for $1m to support South Australia's Community Improvement Through Youth Scheme. Given the Government's priority that youth unemployment can be best tackled by providing more resources in the skills training area, will the Minister assure the Senate that due consideration will be given to the South Australian Government's proposal in the light of South Australia's particular problems, especially in relation to longer term unemployed youth?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not aware of the South Australian Government's specific requirement of $1m, although I was aware that it was interested in a community youth scheme with some support from the Commonwealth Government. As I understand it, State Ministers and the Federal Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs are meeting in Darwin, I think tomorrow, and I believe other States have also requested that the Community Youth Support Scheme be discussed at that meeting. I am not able to say what the outcome of those discussions might be. If requests of the kind posed in this question were made, I am sure that the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs would need to refer them to the Commonwealth Government for consideration of whether they were the best way to meet some of the difficulties mentioned earlier this week and following the announcement of the discontinuation of the CYSS scheme as from 31 October. Following the meeting to be held in Darwin of the relevant State Ministers, we may be in a position to make some comment on the requests that I understand are coming from State governments.

—I ask the Acting Minister for Health whether he is aware of the report released this week by a committee of the Australian Academy of Science which related to lead intake. Is the Minister aware that, whilst the committee was established in response to anxiety about the danger of airborne lead from car exhausts, the findings show that lead from this source contributes less than a quarter of the lead absorbed by adults and less than a tenth of the lead absorbed by children? However, the report warns that babies may be at risk from the lead solder in cans of food. On the basis of those findings, what action does the Federal Government intend to take, given the conclusion of the committee that it would probably be wise to reduce all main sources of lead as far as is practicable, because of the effects on children and the possibility that even low exposure to lead can be a health hazard?

—I was aware of the danger from lead solder in cans and of the greater contribution this makes to the lead burden than exhaust, particularly for the young, and for that reason I appreciate the honourable senator's question. I will look up the Academy of Science report on lead intake and I will find out what the Government is doing about it. I point out to the honourable senator that it is not only the very young who face a danger from lead intake. When I was a trainee doctor in Tennessee we had a lot of lead poisoning. We discovered that that was because people made their illicit liquor-moonshine-in car radiators. The lead leached out of the car radiators and we saw a lot of adults with lead poisoning. Nevertheless, the question which the honourable senator raises is very significant. She does want to know what action is being taken on the appreciation that there are different sources of lead burden. I undertake to get that information for her.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I draw the Minister's attention to a letter we both have received from the Council President of Angurugu, Groote Eylandt, in which the Council states three reasons why it will not take part or assist in any way in the forthcoming National Aboriginal Conference election. One of the reasons stated is that decisions were taken by the NAC executive without any reference to the Aboriginal people and the Council referred particularly to a decision to boycott the Commonwealth Games in Brisbane. Will the Minister comment on this matter and advise whether the Government intends to take any action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a copy of a letter which the President of the Angurugu Council on Groote Eylandt, Mr Jambana Lalara, had sent to the Chairman of the NAC indicating that the Council will not take part in the forthcoming NAC election and that it will not assist in any way. I thought that the Council had set out three reasons, and I am not sure whether they are the same three as the honourable senator has raised. The Council asserted that the NAC representative is seldom seen. I cannot comment on that. The Council said that the election in this area favours the biggest community. It said that decisions are taken by the NAC executive without reference to the Aboriginal people. Obviously, I am disappointed if any Aboriginal community should adopt this position in relation to the NAC election. I have already written to Mr Lalara, encouraging him and his community to participate in the election to be held on 17 October.

ANSWER.PARA: I just make the point that the NAC is an effective forum. The Conference has established itself since 1977 as an effective voice for Aboriginal people where their views are expressed and debated. In addition, the NAC executive recently assumed an advisory role to the Minister, replacing the former Council for Aboriginal Development. I suppose the only other thing to say is that I am aware of special difficulties faced within the Northern Territory in the more traditional communities in relation to their representation on the NAC. Put very simply, the size of the electorates, 4,000 or 5,000 people or whatever it is-this covers several traditional communities-means that it is difficult for someone from one community to represent others. We will take this under study after the NAC election with a view to trying to make some special arrangements for Northern Territory communities with the agreement of the whole of the NAC. I will be disappointed if the Groote Eylandt community does not take part. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the publisher in South Australia of Orion Classics, a Mr Horgan, made a claim that a recent novel Goodbye Janette by Harold Robbins was printed under a new title Lauren by Ruth Adams and submitted this book, this spurious book of course, for classification.

It was submitted to the censorship officers of my Department only because they have to give a certificate that it would not be a prohibited import under the Customs regulations before the book can obtain bounty under the Bounty (Books) Act. That is why the book was submitted. It has nothing to do with the censorship policy generally. That is the first thing to understand.
—Shouldn't you read both books over the weekend?

ANSWER.PARA: The substantial part of the question is about the consistency of censorship policy. Problems arise in many ways. The fact of the matter is that I have been emphasising to the officers of my Department in regard to the censorship of films that as far as possible a consistent policy ought to be followed. TALK.START.PARA: —(Victoria-Minister for Finance)-For the information of honourable senators, I table the result of an investigation by the Department of Finance on Estimating Practices of the Department of Industrial Relations and the Industrial Relations Bureau. Accompanying the report is a statement on the matter.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, I present a report on the Committee's reference concerning the Australian Dairy Corporation and its Asian subsidiaries, together with the transcript of evidence taken.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In presenting the report on behalf of the Committee, I wish to refer to the fact that the report is lengthy and detailed and I see little point in taking up the Senate's time in a recitation of its contents. Included in the report is a summary chapter and a summary of the recommendations requiring action. In essence the changes recommended by the report are these: So far as legislation is concerned, the Committee considers that the Minister for Primary Industry should be given a formal power of direction over the Australian Dairy Corporation to ensure the accountability to Parliament of those responsible for the Australian Dairy Corporation's actions. If Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd is to continue operating in its present form, then the Dairy Produce Act 1924 should be amended so as to give specific power to the ADC to create a subsidiary to engage in these activities. The Department of Primary Industry member of the ADC should in future be a non-voting member and not a full member as at present. Section 5 of the Dairy Produce Act 1924 should be amended to insert a provision specifying the primary duty of board members to the Board as a whole in the resolution of any conflicts of interest. The Dairy Produce Act should be amended to require the ADC to report to Parliament every six months. The relevant legislation should be amended to ensure that authorities are not able to create subsidiaries without prior parliamentary knowledge and ministerial approval and that Ministers inform the Parliament within 15 sitting days of the establishment of such subsidiaries.

SPEECH.PARA: So far as ministerial practice is concerned, we recommend that all types of significant ministerial involvement in the Australian Dairy Corporation should be by way of formal written direction. Directions should be tabled within 15 sitting days of being made except where commercial confidentiality is involved in which case they should be tabled as soon as possible with an appropriate explanation and included in the ADC's next annual report. If the Dairy Corporation or its subsidiaries is in breach of Australia's treaty obligations we believe that the Minister must direct the ADC to cease that breach. This should be done by way of a formal direction which is recorded in writing and brought to the attention of the Parliament as soon as possible. The Minister should also be obliged to ensure that the direction is complied with once given. The Minister for Primary Industry, noting the Committee's view expressed in paragraph 12.33, should make a more explicit statement on the question of the ownership of the Dairy Industry Stabilisation Fund than that which was made in the Minister's memorandum dated 26 June 1979. In the event that Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd is sold the Government should direct that the proceeds be paid into the Dairy Industry Stabilisation Fund.

So far as departmental practice is concerned, the Committee recommended that the Department of Primary Industry should keep the Australian Dairy Corporation informed of Australia's treaty obligations. The Department should draw the Australian Dairy Corporation's attention to any breach, or anticipated breach, of these obligations and also inform the Minister of any breaches by the Corporation or its subsidiaries. The Department should issue and publish broad guidelines to the Dairy Corporation to govern its practices in relation to expenditure controls.

So far as Australian Dairy Corporation practice is concerned, the ADC should be given 12 months to establish and implement over Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd effective expenditure controls, guidelines for the authorisation of recurrent expenditure, procedures for the resolution of conflicts of interest, standards consistent with stock exchange requirements for Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd reports to the ADC and to Parliament and control procedures and reporting requirements to satisfy the Auditor-General. The Dairy Corporation should be responsible for maintaining a written record of ministerial communications. These ministerial communications should be published in the ADC annual report. The Corporation should ensure that its subsidiaries are informed of Australia's treaty obligations and that no breaches of those obligations are incurred by those subsidiaries. ADC nominated directors of the Asian subsidiaries should report regularly to the ADC, particularly on matters which impinge on Government policy. The annual reports and audited financial statements of the subsidiaries should be incorporated in the ADC's annual report to Parliament.

The Australian Dairy Corporation should take all steps in its power to ensure that Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd reports sufficiently and should apply any necessary sanctions such as the replacement of ADI (HK) Ltd's directors. The ADC and Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd should ensure that they do not become involved in activities such as bribery, corruption, tax evasion and secret commissions and other unethical practices regarded as unacceptable in the country involved. Funds should not be paid to individuals without an adequate system to ensure that they will eventually be paid to their rightful recipients and that this can be subject to audit certification. Consideration should be given to not appointing Australian dairy produce manufacturers to the boards of Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd and the other joint venture companies of ADC. If the Dairy Industry Stabilisation Fund is to remain in existence it should continue to be expended in accordance with section 11 of the Dairy Industry Act 1924.

So far as the Auditor-General's Office is concerned, it is recommended that one auditor only should be appointed to audit both the Dairy Corporation and Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd and that that auditor should be the Auditor-General. The Auditor-General should report, on both section 63P of the Audit Act and other reports on the accounts and records of authorities, to the Parliament under his general reporting provision. If the reports contain commercially confidential material they should be made available in the first instance to a parliamentary committee, if necessary on a confidential basis. The Committee indicates to the Senate that it will review the activities of the Australian Dairy Corporation and its Asian subsidiaries in approximately 12 months to see whether the changes recommended in our report have been implemented. In addition, we will keep the matter of ministerial power of appointment to authorities under review.

I refer briefly to the fact that, as has been indicated in statements made to the House of Representatives, certain matters relating to the affairs of Asia Dairy Industries were reported by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) to the police. The Committee was careful to avoid any inquiry which would impinge upon matters which had been referred to the police and deliberately avoided any examination of those matters. They will no doubt be dealt with in the long-awaited ministerial statement relating to the police inquiry. I thank the Senate for the opportunity to make a brief statement pointing out some of the major recommendations. The other aspects of the Committee's findings are contained in the report itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I simply want to comment briefly on the report in my capacity as a member of the Committee. No doubt the shadow Minister for Primary Industry, Senator Walsh, will want to comment at rather greater length and with more elaboration than it would be appropriate for me to do as a member of the Committee. I simply make the point that it is a complex report involving a very large cast of characters, engaged as they were over a number of years in a number of different kinds of activity and involving government at a number of different levels. Essentially, I believe that the report must be left to speak for itself. The important points to appreciate about it are, firstly, that its findings and recommendations are, without exception, unanimous. Secondly, the language of those findings, as will be evident from Senator Peter Rae's summary account of some of the recommendations, is careful, precise, non-tendentious and in no instance goes beyond what a reasonably objective observer could conclude from the evidence that was available to the Committee.

The length of the report and the care with which it has been written will undoubtedly mean that for its full implications to be appreciated will take some time. What is clear from even the most cursory examination that someone might give the report is that none of the leading characters or organisations involved emerges with their credibility completely intact. In the case of the Australian Dairy Corporation, it is evident that that statutory authority has been erratically and for the most part very poorly administered. The behaviour of Asia Dairy Industries and other Asian subsidiaries has left a good deal to be desired by almost any criterion, not least in terms of the understanding of the officers of those corporations and those to whom they are responsible of basic notions of accountability to the public parent which created them or sustained their existence. The behaviour of the Department of Primary Industry and its senior relevant officers when it has not been simply incompetent has been positively weak, vacillating and self-serving.

Finally, it is evident from even the most superficial reading of the report and the way in which the conclusions are written that the behaviour of the relevant Minister, Mr Sinclair, has been such that it is difficult to believe that his departure from ministerial office can be much longer delayed-if the same standards of probity are to be applied to him as have come to be applied in recent years to other former leading lights of this Government. However, I repeat that all of the matters with which this report deals must ultimately be left to speak for themselves. The preparation of the report has been a prolonged and difficult task because of the acute sensitivity of the whole range of issues involved. I repeat that what must be appreciated about the report and everything in it is that all of the conclusions and recommendations come from a bipartisan committee on a completely unanimous basis. I hope that, accordingly, this Parliament will give due weight to those recommendations.
