The paper is one which we are told has been in the hands of the Senate for, what, 10 minutes? We are now getting into a debate which might be more suitable on some other form of motion but which is certainly not suitable on the motion to take note of this paper. I have not taken a point of order prior to this time on the basis of the sorts of statements that have been made about the Ministers, but I draw your attention, Mr President, to the language which is being used and I would propose to take further points of order if it continues.

—Order! Senator Walsh, before you resume I say from the chair that I have been listening very closely to your remarks. I would hope that you would confine your remarks to the report itself. I accept that what you have said has been used in the collective term but I do suggest to you from the Chair that you do not use derogatory remarks about an individual. I ask you to be very careful in that area and at the same time, if you can, to confine your remarks so that they are related more to the report itself.

—On the matter of relevance, I have cited chapter 9, paragraph 38, of the report, to which the remarks I am making are directly relevant. I refer to the question of whether statements made by the then Minister in the House of Representatives in fact were accurate. One telephone call which one judge believed to be improper got a Liberal Minister the sack. National Country Party Ministers with common records of administrative negligence, parliamentary concealment and obfuscation survive. Apparently in this Government the National Country Party is inviolate. It is ironic to recall a statement made by the former Minister for Primary Industry on 21 November 1977, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Our standards are very high indeed and the standards that I have set I believe maintain exactly the same standards as anyone would wish a person in high office to set.

It is ironic also to recall the sanctimonious prime ministerial humbug about ministerial propriety with which we used to be plagued. If the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) lacks the courage or the common decency to clean up his own Ministry, it is time that the Liberal Party of Australia got rid of him. It is not surprising that culpable negligence at the highest levels filters down through departments into authorities under their control. I will take a couple of short quotes from pages 355 and 357 of the Committee's report relating to its findings concerning a member-in fact the Vice-Chairman-of the Australian Dairy Corporation board. The report states:

We are not able to conclude whether Mr Pyle did in fact, disconnect the speedo or whether he used this statement to attempt to explain the duplicated claims for expenses. Certainly, it makes it impossible to establish the extent of the duplication. The Committee considers that Mr Pyle's behaviour in relation to the disconnection of the speedo speaks for itself. We are not concerned to decide whether Mr Pyle's actions were, in his words, 'stupid more than dishonest' or whether they were dishonest more than stupid, they were certainly a combination of both.
The Committee goes on to state:
The system used by the ADC for the reimbursement of the travel expenses of the Deputy Chairmen (and Acting Chairman for 6 months)-
That is, Mr Pyle-
was unsatisfactory. It was capable of simple abuse and was simply abused.

In other words, the Committee has found that the Vice-Chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation has been double dipping, is in effect guilty of fraud and has been robbing dairy farmers. He holds office at the Minister's pleasure. Surely he should be sacked. But with the present Minister's record, can he sack anyone?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! You are going very close to transgressing the Standing Orders. There is an implied statement in that and I warn you not to go any further.
—Very well, Mr President.
—I hope you take heed of that warning, Senator.

—I shall. Another member of the Corporation who also holds office at ministerial pleasure is Mr Bennett, who was an active agent in the cover-up if not in the major villainies. His fitness to retain his position on the Corporation board must be called into question. All of the people who have been exposed in this report very nearly got away with it. Mr Hayden asked a question, originally more than two years ago, that produced a volley of abuse. Some came from Mr Sinclair-I have already quoted some of that-and some came from other quarters. In particular, I quote three short sections from the Primary Industry Newsletter of 5 September 1979 in which, in response to Mr Hayden's question which, I emphasise, did not name any individual or even any corporation, this was written:

SPEECH.PARA: Are Australia's Parliaments to become havens for scheming character assassination? Is the ancient shield of ''Parliamentary privilege'' to be used time and again to destroy men, their reputations, their characters and their livelihoods, without recourse of law?
Are the Politics of the Smear to be allowed to ride roughshod over natural justice?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, might I suggest to you that you bring your remarks back to relating more directly to the report? You are ranging rather widely in your comments.

—Mr President, I am quoting comments made more than two years ago on the very issue of misfeasance, as the Leader of the Opposition originally put it, in a statutory authority under the control of the Corporation; the very misfeasance which ultimately led to the Senate inquiry and the production of this report. The Primary Industry Newsletter of 5 September continued:

SPEECH.PARA: PIN found nothing in its ''investigation'' to suggest any wrong doing, let alone any ''misappropriation''.
PIN went on:
After evaluating the information available to it and making some inquiries of its own, PIN concluded that the allegations being made were without substance . . .

PIN also stated that there were wild allegations of very large sums of money having been involved. It was found by the Committee that a sum in excess of $1m which disappeared into a bank account in Asia could not be traced. That might not be a very large sum to the proprietor of PIN, but it is a very large sum to most people. The theme played in that issue of PIN was consistently played in subsequent issues of PIN, reinforced from time to time with attacks on nosey politicians and replayed by a slothful and sycophantic agricultural Press. With the sole and honourable exception of the Weekly Times, the agricultural Press gave no or negligible coverage to either the original Auditor-General's investigations or the subsequent Committee hearings. Perhaps the prize for the most undistinguished member of the agricultural media on this issue should be awarded to the Australian Broadcasting Commission's rural department. The reaction among the agricultural establishment to the disclosures which have come out to date was that, if they threatened the establishment, it did not want to know about it.

The present Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, who become Minister in September 1979, which was soon after this matter became a question for public discussion, consistently refused to table the original Auditor-General's report received by his predecessor in August 1979. He has given a variety of conflicting reasons for not doing so. In April 1980 he claimed in the House that the Auditor-General had advised him not to table the report, that it would be inappropriate to table the report. That question was pursued at Senate Estimates committee hearings in April 1980 and Mr Taylor, the Assistant Auditor-General, explained then-and subsequently by letter-that the advice given to the Minister was that there were certain reports the tabling of which was mandatory, and there were other reports the tabling of which was optional. The Auditor-General's report on the Dairy Corporation fell into that latter category. A ministerial option to table the report, or notification that there is a ministerial option to table the report, is very far removed from an Auditor-General's advice that it would be inappropriate to table the report. Presumably the present Minister's comprehension of the English language is not so feeble that he is not aware of that very important distinction. However, he still refuses to table that report.

In June 1980 sections of the report were leaked to me. On 18 August 1980 Mr Nixon sent certain matters to the Australian Federal Police for investigation. On 24 October 1980 and 11 March 1981 he received reports as a result of those police investigations. According to an answer given to a parliamentary question, he sent those reports to the Attorney-General (Senator Durack). As far as is known-the Minister was asked a question about that this morning-the reports are still buried there, although information obtained since Question Time suggests that within a few days those reports will be either released or acted upon. Nothing, apparently, activates an inert Minister like a shot across the bows.

In August 1980 I tabled the leaked sections of the Auditor-General's report which, I think it is fair to claim, provided the basis for the ultimate committee inquiry of which the report which has just been tabled is the final product. If that Auditor-General's report had not been substantially leaked, it appears from the record that Mr Nixon would have continued to suppress information relevant to this matter. He would have sat on that report for ever. A mutually supportive white wash group comprising, among other people, Mr Nixon, Mr Pyle, Mr Anderson and, to a lesser degree, Mr Bennett, assisted in the cover-up.

With regard to Mr Anderson, the transcript of the March 1979 hearing provides clear prima facie evidence for at least two charges of perjury. The Committee probably decided not to press ahead with those charges on the grounds that a prosecution might well be futile. There is a marked and unexplained contrast connected with the ministerial decision in April 1980 to extend Asia Dairy Industries trading powers in dairy products-it was under a very dark cloud at the time-to biscuits, fruit juices and probably some other commodities. For some years ADI had dealt with negligible quantities of Australian dairy products and had traded mainly in the dairy products of third countries, which were sold in South East Asia. It seems extraordinary that a subsidiary of a statutory corporation trading only in Asia, trading mostly in goods sourced from and sold to foreign countries and trading scarcely at all in the product for which it was originally established should have its trading power widened in that way at that time when it was under a very heavy cloud of suspicion.

I contrast that with the more recent decision to instruct the Australian Wool Corporation to dispose of the Australian Wool Testing Authority, a body which operates entirely in Australia and which deals entirely with Australian products. I hope that at some future date we will get from whoever happens to be the Minister some elucidation of government decisions on those questions. What has really been exposed here is yet another sordid scandal involving the Department of Primary Industry and the corporations and services under its control and the Ministers responsible for it. If ministerial heads do not roll as a result of these disclosures Australia will have regressed even further into banana republicanism than it has already in nearly seven years of Fraser Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations is probably the most eagerly awaited report since the report of the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange was put down. We are confronted with an unfortunate situation in a number of ways. The first is that another major primary industry in this country has had its overseas image tarnished and its reputation in terms of fair dealing exposed. It is a pity that the Department of Primary Industry has not been able, in the time that these allegations have come forward, to change its procedures sufficiently to meet the types of things that this report quite correctly suggests ought to have taken place. It is also a pity that the Senate was not able to see the report at the same time as the media obviously was. It is obvious from Australian Broadcasting Commisssion radio this morning that this report has found its way into the hands not of senators who ought to have been the first to actually receive it but into the hands of reporters. It seems to me that that is a subsidiary matter in terms of not only this report but also other reports. The methodology by which these reports are handled may need looking into and, probably, urgent revision. I do not think this chamber is being treated fairly if it is possible for people outside the Parliament to have access to something that senators here cannot have access to. I hope this matter will be taken up in a short time. It is hoped that the various recommendations of the report will be debated at greater length than we can debate them today.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the political matter which is obviously contained within certain elements of this report. If this chamber is not given some reasonable explanation for the issues which this report has raised and documented I believe the forms which are available to this chamber ought to be used to puruse those elements until such time as the responsible Minister has given a response which is acceptable to the chamber. I foreshadow later moves if an adequate response is not forthcoming. On occasions in the past where the Senate was frustrated in ascertaining material, adequate forms were available by which that material could eventually have been ferreted out and tabled. I hope the Government, having received this report, will look at those politically sensitive matters and bring forward a detailed explanation of the events outlined in the report.

I think it is important that this chamber place on record its debt to the members of the Committee for what obviously is an extremely detailed and thorough report into an area of extraordinary importance to our primary industry. We hope that, unlike to so many reports that are tabled in this place, urgent attention is paid to this report and that we do not have to wait two years for a government response, as so often is the case. Let us not go through the tedious rigmarole which we had to go through in relation to the meat industry. Having received a bipartisan report of a committee which has looked at all areas thoroughly and has given its recommendations, let us not have another departmental committee sitting on a report to see what the Government will do about it. Let us hope that in a short time-I do not see why it ought to proceed past the non-sitting weeks which we are coming up to-the Government will be able to give a response as to what it will be doing in relation to this report. I hope it will give a favourable response to the detailed recommendations contained in the report. I commend that type of action to the Government. The Australian Democrats will be eagerly waiting for that indication on the part of the Government. I reiterate that if this is not forthcoming we will pursue other forms in this chamber to make sure that it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak briefly on the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations in relation to the Australian Dairy Corporation and its Asian subsidiaries. Firstly, I refer to the in terrorem tactics that Senator Macklin has just directed at the Government in relation to this report. I find it quite incredible that senators come into this Chamber without any experience of Government-I am one of them-and proceed to tell Ministers how they should react to reports produced in this chamber. A report takes almost 12 months to prepare, after careful analysis. It makes an enormous number of recommendations. Clearly they are recommendations which require, firstly, ministerial and then departmental investigation in depth, then recommendations to Cabinet, then decisions of Cabinet and finally implementation, possibly by way of legislation. Yet honourable senators come into this chamber and say that because we have produced a bipartisan report we ought to be able to respond to it within a few months, and if we do not they will use the procedures of this House to do something or other to us. The power seems to have gone to the heads of the Australian Democrats. I am pleased to see that members of the Opposition joined with us last night in order to show where the power really lies.

SPEECH.PARA: I see that most members of the media have departed from the chamber, having heard the exaggerated and emotive language flowing from the vituperative tongue of our colleague, Senator Walsh. No doubt they now have the headlines that they can explode across the newspapers this afternoon and tomorrow morning, and reports for the television and radio. I hope that rather than listen to the language of our colleague, Senator Walsh, the media, the honourable senators in this chamber and the public will read carefully the words of the report rather than guess at what has been said. I draw the attention of the Senate to paragraph 9.38 on page 174 of the report which is the paragraph that Senator Walsh made so much of but did not quote. That paragraph states:
The Committee concludes that on the balance of probabilities, Mr Sinclair's recollection of the events was not as reliable as that of Mr Webster . . .

That is a valid conclusion that a committee can draw on the basis of evidence, and one can draw one's conclusions about the recollection of people in relation to this matter. But as to guessing at the words that are used, it appals me that Senator Walsh, with all due respect, is able to come into the Senate and make his slanderous statements, without justifying them. I do not wish to comment in great detail on the contents of the report. The report stands on its own two feet. I do hope, however, that the concentration which Senator Walsh has given to this paragraph will not allow honourable senators, the public and the media to be distracted from the other items in the report. The report contains 350-odd pages and a great deal of detail. I refer in particular to the problem of statutory authorities and subsidiaries which subsume unto themselves power beyond the power which the statutory authority has in itself so that, for example, Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd is able to trade, notwithstanding the fact that it is not buying Australian skim milk powder but is buying skim milk powder from other nations. Is this a power that it ought to have?

As to the question of whether the Government should dispose of Asia Dairy Industries, what should be its future role generally, and the flow of information from subsidiaries of statutory authorities to statutory authorities, to the Minister, to the department and to the Parliament-all of these matters are of vital importance to this Parliament. In particular I refer to chapter 16 in relation to applying the lessons of this investigation to statutory authorities generally and the creation by them of subsidiaries, the behaviour of subsidiaries and the behaviour of statutory authorities generally. I commend the details of the words of the report to the Senate rather than general guessing by honourable senators as to what the report contains.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I am or was a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations that inquired into the Australian Dairy Corporation and its Asian subsidiaries, it was not my intention to speak on the report until my colleague, Senator Lewis, who also was a member of the Committee, had spoken this morning. I merely want to say that all members of the Committee who sat on the inquiry put a tremendous amount of effort, work and thought into the inquiry and into the preparation of the report. The conclusions and findings that have been reached were reached after a great deal of consideration, coolly, calmly and collectively, and after a sieving of all the evidence that had been presented to the Committee and which had been taken by the Committee both in public and in private. The recommendations that have been made have been made unanimously in a genuine attempt to assist statutory authorities in general and in particular the Australian Dairy Corporation and Asia Dairy Industries and in a genuine belief that all of the recommendations that have been put forward need the earnest consideration of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to the remarks of my colleague, Senator Lewis, concerning Senator Walsh, I merely want to say that in respect of Senator Lewis's comments about paragraph 9.38 of the report, he emphasised one sentence of the Committee's report, when he said:
The Committee concludes that on the balance of probabilities, Mr Sinclair's recollection of the events was not as reliable as that of Mr Webster.
I merely want to add the next sentence of the report which states:
In other words, it appears to the Committee that on the balance of probabilities, Mr Sinclair was told of the terms of the compromise which necessarily involved a continuing breach of GATT.

That is a very serious conclusion and a very serious finding. It was a unanimous conclusion and a unanimous finding of the six members of the Committee, four of whom, I hasten to point out, are distinguished lawyers, and two of whom-one of whom is me-are former Ministers of the Crown. Therefore, I would certainly hope that all of my Senate colleagues would view that conclusion seriously and with concern. I point out that the Committee has said that on the balance of probabilities the then Minister, Mr Sinclair, was told of the terms of the compromise which necessarily involved a continuing breach of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. That is a very serious matter so far as Parliament is concerned. I believe it is a matter that has to be cleared up and I would urge the Government to give it close consideration. Having made that brief comment, I suggest that the remarks that Senator Walsh has made are very pertinent to that section of the Committee's report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had no intention of entering this debate on the motion that the Senate take note of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations until Senator Lewis made some very uncomplimentary remarks about my colleague, Senator Walsh. He talked about Senator Walsh having a vituperative tongue and making slanderous statements. Senator Lewis said nothing about the vituperative tongues and slanderous statements being used against Senator Walsh by members of the rural community-in particular by that discreditor, the editor of the Primary Industry Newsletter-who tried to discredit Senator Walsh during the last election campaign when he was the primary industry spokesman for the Australian Labor Party. When one has moved around the rural community and has listened to some of the most slanderous statements levelled at Senator Walsh for having had the persistence and temerity to raise this matter in the Senate, one wonders now why Senator Lewis says the same things about Senator Walsh, when he defended himself by quoting from the report.

SPEECH.PARA: This document completely vindicates the persistence of Senator Walsh in bringing this matter to the attention of the Senate. Had he not done so, as he said in his speech, the matter of the $1m which was falsely used and misappropriated-the Committee could not find what happened to it-would have been swept under the carpet. I think the Senate should give due credit to Senator Walsh for his persistence. He does not pull any punches when he finds that things are not all that they should be. I want to give credit not only to him but also to the members of the Committee who took this matter on board and who brought down a report to this chamber which completely vindicates the statements and claims by Senator Walsh who sought an inquiry. I was involved in this matter to some small degree when I gave notice of a motion on behalf of Senator Walsh when he was given a small holiday from this chamber. Had it not been for the honourable senator's persistence, Mr Nixon would have been off the hook. He would not have been under challenge today; neither would Mr Sinclair.

If this sort of thing had happened during the reign of the Whitlam Government honourable senators opposite would have bayed like wolves and called for resignations and sackings. The way Mr Whitlam conducted his Government, in his wisdom, he would have seen to it that had any Minister acted as these Ministers have acted-it has been stated in this report that they did act this way-they would have been removed from office. We wait with very intense interest to see whether this will be the fate of the Ministers talked about in this report, because the Federal Parliament of this country has to be consistent. We cannot make fish of one and fowl of the other where public money is involved. No doubt this matter will be dissected by the Press and by everybody who has an interest in it in the days to come. I hope a full debate takes place in this Parliament and that remedial measures are taken to see that no cover-ups like this are attempted ever again by Ministers of a Federal parliament. Senator Walsh was seeking only to have the matters aired so that it could be judged whether he was right or wrong. Senator Lewis now is a little concerned that Senator Walsh, in fact, has been judged to be right in regard to the statements and queries he brought before this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you aware that I am a member of this Committee?

—I am aware of that. I gained the impression when the honourable senator was speaking that he was trying to repudiate some of those recommendations made in the report. He selectively quoted from passages in the report. It was left to our colleague, Senator McClelland, who was also a member of the Committee, to complete the quotation embodied in paragraph 9.38. Senator Lewis left out the relevant part. He also did not refer in his remarks to the last two lines on page 176, although he has put his name to the report. Under the heading 'Minister', paragraph 9.42 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Ministerial inaction in the face of a known continuing breach cannot be condoned.

The honourable senator never mentioned that when he spoke; it was left to members on this side to pull out the relevant points. I am not conversant with the whole of the document although I did sit in on the inquiry for a couple of days to listen to what was being said. While this inquiry was going on, and even before it was set up, I was most concerned that attempts were made to make my colleague, Senator Walsh, the then Labor Party spokesman on primary industry, appear to be the villian of the piece-that he did not know what he was talking about, that he had set a hare going just to bring about some discredit to Mr Sinclair and Mr Nixon. The evidence given to this Commitee was given under oath, and I have every faith in the job done by the members of the Committee. As a colleague has pointed out, four of them are lawyers-he said they were all prominent lawyers, although I have some doubt about that at times, particularly in regard to one of them-and he said the other two members were ex-Ministers of the Crown.

I am very pleased that this report has now come into the Parliament and I am very pleased that my colleague, Senator Walsh, has been shown to have a clean skin and that he was doing his duty as he saw it, not only to the general public but also to the dairy farmers of Australia who had to place their confidence in Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd. I am afraid that confidence was sadly astray. I hope that in the days to come remedial action will be taken as a result of this report and we will never have to see another report like this come into the Federal Parliament which shows Ministers of the Crown in a very bad light. I do not know whether anyone else wishes to speak on this matter, but we do not want to see the debate die. It has to be left on the Notice Paper. Perhaps my colleague, Senator Georges, has a few words to say; so I will resume my seat.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to speak on this matter; I just want to make certain it does not disappear off the Notice Paper. I do not know whether the Minister is going to close the debate, although I think Senator Rae is the only person who can do that. If the motion is to be that the debate be adjourned, I have nothing to say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —To clarify this point, my understanding is that the motion is that the Senate take note of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. I indicate now that it is my intention, after a very brief contribution, to seek leave to continue my remarks. A number of honourable senators, in speaking to the motion, have indicated their concern that there should be a Government response to the report. It is understandable that the Senate and the Committee should want the Government's response to what appears to be a detailed series of recommendations on a range of matters. I think all honourable senators will understand that I in no way now wish to give that definitive Government response. The report is one of some 370-plus pages. It goes into great detail on a series of matters. I received the report only shortly after the tabling statement was made by the Chairman of the Committee. I have not had an opportunity to read it and the Government has not had an opportunity to consider it.

SPEECH.PARA: Having glanced through it very quickly, I accept the words of Senator Evans who says this is a complex report which has a large cast of characters and deals with a very wide range of matters. I draw the Senate's attention to that because I think it is rather bold of any honourable senator who is not a member of the Commitee to rise in his place within minutes of the report being presented and to offer his congratulations to the Committee for the careful and thorough way in which it has done its job. I would have thought any honourable senators wanting to maintain credibility in this place might suspend their judgment on that until they have had a chance at least to read the report and make some personal judgment on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now you are reflecting on members of the Committee.

—I am making the comment that for an individual senator to purport to pass judgment on this report without having read it simply indicates that one is prepared to take a stance on the basis of general reputation and on the basis that one may or may not like the result of the report. I do not intend to fall into that trap. I will therefore make very few comments on the report because of my own inability to read it in the matter of minutes I have had it.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I welcome the fact that Senator Lewis did bring the debate back to the words which are used in paragraph 9.38. He quoted a part of that paragraph and made the point that the journalists who had been here for the early part of the debate were likely to write in terms of the gloss put upon the Committee's findings by the speech of Senator Walsh. It was useful that Senator Lewis did that, and I commend those people who are examining the matter to read carefully the words of the report itself rather than at this stage the gloss put on it by honourable senators who have made comment in this debate. I say that with the greatest respect to all honourable senators. We are assured by those honourable senators who have spoken that the matter is a difficult one and that the report has been prepared carefully. Like Senator Lewis, I simply say that the words of paragraph 9.38 ought to be referred to rather than the gloss which has been put upon them.

There is one other matter I mention because I think it ought to be of interest and concern to all honourable senators. In flicking through this report, I noticed, in the some 30 to 40 pages of it which seem to relate to the paragraph which has received so much attention, that in the course of the Committee's inquiries on at least one occasion there was a leak which found its way into the media, a leak which was complained of and a leak for which expressions of apology were made to Mr Sinclair. I refer to the letter appearing on page 162 of the report which refers to an earlier letter from Senator Peter Rae to Mr Sinclair which appears on page 159 of the report and is in these terms:

Regrettably, and to date inexplicably, the fact that I was instructed by the Committee to seek to discuss this with you were leaked to the Sydney Morning Herald. Without accepting the responsibility for this my Committee expresses its regret that this has transpired.

On page 162 we find that Mr Sinclair in a letter to Senator Peter Rae inter alia expressed his appreciation of the expression of regret. I mention that because on AM this morning there was a report from Simon Nasht about this report which was to come into this place. Mr Nasht reported:

That the Committee has unanimously decided that the weight of evidence must be considered in Mr Webster's favour. The Minister's version must therefore be, in the Committee's opinion, in serious doubt.

I hope that, in a spirit of concern about the role of the Senate, the role of the Parliament and its proper relationship to the public, the Executive and so on, there will be bipartisan concern about the fact that that report was on AM this morning. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that it may well involve a breach of privilege. I do so at this stage merely to put that on the record as a possibility. I hope that it is a matter of concern to all senators when the proper procedures are not followed, particularly in a matter which raises the sorts of allegations which have been made in this debate. At this early stage, I simply-not in any sense trying to be definitive on the matter-draw the Senate's attention to that possibility as one which I think we should also be considering when we examine this report and its implications.

I close my remarks at this stage simply by saying that, of course, the Government will be giving the report very careful consideration. It will, of course, respond to the Parliament and, in particular, the Senate, with respect to the matters which have been raised. I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

Meat Export (Penalties) Bill 1981

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for severe penalties to be imposed on any person who contravenes the provisions of certain regulations under the Exports (Meat) Regulations. The necessity for this course of action to be taken has been brought about by the recent discovery of fraudulent misrepresentation with regard to meat shipments to the United States of America. The areas of difficulty which have been identified as a result of the recent events are covered by regulations 33A, 58 and 59 (1) of the Exports (Meat) Regulations. These relate to the misuse of inspection stamps, alteration or interference with descriptions, tags et cetera and the making of false or misleading statements in pursuance of the respective regulations.

The existing maximum penalties for any breach of the regulations is $100. We are therefore amending the Customs Act, among other things, to allow this maximum to be increased to $1,000. Is is not considered appropriate to have a penalty higher than this incorporated in a regulation. However, the Government is strongly of the view that further provision needs to be made for much higher penalties to exist for offences of the nature I have just outlined. This is the reason for the Meat Export (Penalties) Bill. It provides for penalties to be imposed on anyone who contravenes those sections of the Exports (Meat) Regulations referred to previously. Any contravention of these regulations would make the offenders guilty of an indictable offence and consequently subject to penalties of up to $100,000 or imprisonment of up to 5 years or both.

These new and severe penalties are indicative of the Government's desire to ensure effective deterrents. However, as is normal in penalty legislation of this kind, the Bill also makes it possible to proceed against offenders by summary jurisdiction with the lesser penalties of up to $5,000 or imprisonment of up to 1 year or both. Summary jurisdiction requires that the court is satisfied that it is proper to do so and the defendant and the prosecutor consent. It ensures extremely minor offences are not unnecessarily taken to a higher court and in no way undermines the ability of the legal system to impose suitably severe penalties for breaches of the law. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill 1981

This Bill is one of the measures being introduced by the Government to heighten control over exports of meat and livestock from Australia and to increase the penalties currently available for offences against the statutory provisions governing such exports. Specifically, the Bill we are considering is designed to increase the penalty of $2,000 currently specified in the Act for cases where a licenced exporter exports meat or live-stock from Australia in contravention of a condition of his licence. It is proposed that, where a licensee is convicted of an indictable offence, the penalty shall be a fine of up to $100,000 or imprisonment for up to 5 years, or both.

An alternative provision is included for dealing with offences in a court of summary jurisdiction, provided the court sees this as the appropriate course and both the defendant and the prosecutor consent. The penalty in those cases would be a fine of up to $5,000 or imprisonment for up to 1 year, or both. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Commerce (Trade Descriptions) Amendment Bill 1981

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Commerce (Trade Descriptions) Act 1905 to provide for the imposition of higher penalties on any person who knowingly applies any false trade description to foodstuffs intended for or entered for export. Under section 12 of the current legislation, the maximum penalty for such an offence is $200. This is totally inadequate and the purpose of this Bill is to bring the penalty up to a realistic level and in line with that proposed under other associated Bills.

This Bill provides for additional sub-sections to section 12 of the Act whereby anyone who contravenes the provisions of the Act in relation to foodstuffs shall be guilty of an indictable offence and subject to penalties of up to $100,000 or imprisonment for up to 5 years or both. The Bill also makes provision that where appropriate it will be possible to proceed against anyone who contravenes the provisions of the Act by summary jurisdiction with the lesser penalties of fines up to $5,000 or imprisonment for up to one year or both. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Customs (Unlawful Exportation of Food) Amendment Bill 1981

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Customs Act 1901 to increase substantially the penalties in that Act for offences which relate to the unlawful exportation of food. The Government has decided to take this action following the discovery in the United States of America of Australian boneless beef being adulterated with horse and kangaroo meat. The measures contained in this Bill were foreshadowed by my colleague, the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon), in his statement to the other place on 8 September 1981. The penalty for the illegal exportation of any goods other than narcotics is now a pecuniary penalty of $1,000. However section 240 of the Customs Act does provide for a penalty of 3 times the value of the goods in respect of which the offence is committed if the pecuniary penalty is less than 3 times the value of the goods. The potential penalty could, therefore, be much higher than $1,000.

Notwithstanding the potential of section 240 of the Customs Act, the Government is of the view that the penalty for conduct such as that involved in the illegal exportation of horse and kangaroo meat to the USA should be clearly expressed in the legislation as substantial. Accordingly, the penalties for the unlawful exportation of food will be increased by this Bill to a maximum fine of $100,000 or imprisonment for a period not exceeding 5 years, or both. For this purpose, a new offence will be created by clause 5 of the Bill. It will henceforth be an indictable offence to export food which is prohibited by any regulations in force under the Customs Act and the Commerce (Trade Descriptions) Act.

Provision is made in the Bill for a court of summary jurisdiction to hear and determine proceedings in respect of the new offence. Upon conviction that court may impose a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment for a period not exceeding 1 year, or both. The penalty for a contravention of a regulatoin relating to food has also been increased, to a maximum of $1,000. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 24 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Minister for Veterans' Affairs confirm that persons who were accredited as war correspondents by the Australian Government during World War II have been declared eligible to receive Repatriation benefits as an act of grace; if so, will the Minister consider extending this act of grace to the many unaccredited war correspondents who served Australia with equal courage and fortitude.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: War correspondents during World War II do not qualify as 'members of the Forces' as defined in the Repatriation Act 1920 and are, therefore, ineligible for Repatriation benefits on that basis. The requirements for benefits under this authority are that the person must have served with, and under the same conditions as, attested 'members of the Forces'.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Wage Fixing and Industrial Relations Systems: Proposed Inquiry

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 May 1981 (Hansard, page 1649), Senator McIntosh asked the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I preface my question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, by stating that I understand that a Federal-State inquiry is to be conducted into Australia's wage fixing and industrial relations systems, as suggested by the Premier of Western Australia, Sir Charles Court, and that, amongst other things, the inquiry will report on the economic implications of the 35-hour week and the level and effect of industrial disputes. Can the Minister say whether the same inquiry is prepared to take into account the effect of industrial accidents on the economy and, more importantly, on those in the community affected by the lack of proper and uniform safety standards? I point out that industrial accidents are responsible for about three times more lost time in industry than industrial disputes.
The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer:

It is acknowledged that industrial accidents can and do have a considerable impact upon the profitability of an industry in a number of ways, not the least of which is the impact on total labour costs through workers compensation premia. It needs to be recognised that industrial accidents also have a considerable cost in human terms and it is for this reason that the Government has encouraged industry to constantly review work practices with the purpose of minimizing the opportunities for such accidents to occur.

As to whether the Inquiry into Wage Determination and Industrial Relations Systems will address itself to the question of the effects of industrial accidents, I must point out that I am not in a position to indicate to what extent the Inquiry will or will not take such matters into account. That is a matter for the Inquiry to determine in the light of its consideration of the terms of reference. Senator McIntosh will, of course, have an opportunity to put a submission to the Inquiry on any matters he considers to be within its terms of reference.
